coredata.dc:title: Diffusion of an impurity in the hard sphere fluid
coredata.dc:creator: Keyes, T.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The self-diffusion coefficient (D) of a hard sphere of variable size and mass, moving in a solvent of hard spheres of fixed size and mass, is calculated in a version of the ring approximation (RA). It is found that (a) the ring contribution to D vanishes for particles smaller or less massive than the solvent, (b) D reaches a finite limit, which varies with solvent density, as the tagged particle is made infinitely massive at fixed radius, and (c) D becomes infinite, and then negative, as the tagged particle radius is increased. The size and mass dependence of D in the RA is used as the basis of a criticism of the RA itself. It is argued that the repeated ring approximation is needed to provide a good theory for large, massive particles, and also, that “back-scattering” must be added to the RRA for pure fluids at high density.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 51, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 October 1977 DIFFUSION OF AN IMPURITY IN THE HARD SPHERE FLUID * T. KEYES ** Sterling Chemistry Laboratory. Yale University. New Haven. Connecticut 06520, USA Received 11 July 1977 The self-diffusion coefficient (D) of a hard sphere of variable size and mass, moving in a solvent of hard spheres of fixed size and mass, is calculated in a version of the ring approximation (RA). It is found that (a) the ring contribution to D vanishes for particles smaller or less massive than the solvent, (b) D reaches a finite limit, which varies with solvent density, as the tagged particle is made infinitely massive at fixed radius, and (c) D becomes infinite, and then negative, as the tagged particle radius is increased. The size and mass dependence o{D in the RA is used as the basis of a criticism of the RA itself- It is aigued that the repeated ring approximation is needed to provide a good theory for large, massive particles, and also, that "back-scattering" must be added to the RRA for pure fluids at high density. 1. Introduction In 1970, Alder, Gass, and Wainwright (AGW) showed [1] that the self-diffusion coefficient, D, differed significantly from its Enskog value. Dp, in moderately or very dense hard sphere fluids; many theorists [2- 5] have subsequently tried to reproduce the results of AGW. Almost every attempt to cal- culate deviations ofD from D^ has ascribed those deviations to "ring" collisions. The ring approximation (RA) was first introduced into modern hard-sphere kinetic theory by Kawasaki and Oppenheim [6j, and, with subsequent conceptual evolution, is not now precisely defined. Probably the current theory best described as "the" RA is that of Dorfman and Cohen [5], which gives the correct long time behavior of the velocity correlation function. In this letter, we shall refer to any approximation whose essential ingredient is ring collisions as "the" RA, meaning a version of theRA. Within the RA, many sub-levels of approximation [2—5] must be considered before D is obtained. A collision operator is written which is a sum of ring and Enskog parts. A matrix element of the inverse collision operator gives D, and the inversion must be * Supported by NSF grant CHE76-07384. ** Alfred P. Sloan Foundation Fellow. performed approximately- The matrix element is then divided into contributions from hydrodynamic states. The hydrodynamic contributions contain correlation functions which are approximated by interpolation forms valid at short and long times, and the non- hydrodynamic contributions must also be approximat- ed. Recent research has focused on improving the approximations within the RA. All the theories of which we are aware have con- sidered pure fluids. In this letter, we shall present results, in the RA, for the self-diffusion coefficient of a tagged "impurity" hard sphere of variable size (R) and mass (M) moving in a solvent of hard spheres of "unit" size and mass. One might think it premature to study impurity diffusion when a complete theory for pure fluids has yet to be constructed- Of course, ths dynamics of impurity particles is of considerable inherent interest. However, we are mainly interested in the R and M dependence of D because of the light which a knowledge of such dependence sheds upon the validity of the RA itself. We feel strongly that viewing D as a function of R, M and of the density, rather than as a function of the density alone, gives one a superior perspective for the evaluation of approximate versions of kinetic theory. We use the version of the RA given by Mazenko [3] in his second paper on "fully renormalized kinetic theory", denoted here as FRKT II. At this level, 370 Volume 51, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 October 1977 (a) the collision operator is treated as diagonal, (b) the "gaussian approximation" is used for hydrodynamic correlation functions, and (c) the nonhydrodynamic part of the ring operator is evaluated using free particle dynamics. Our approach differs slightly from that of FRKT II in that we have included an extra factor ofg^, the pair distribution at contact in the ring operator; a g* was "missing" [4] from early versions of FRKT. We also assume that the hydrodynamic part of the ring operator contains the same transport coefficients as are being calculated and not, as was assumed in FRKT II, Enskog-approx- imation correlation functions. Although the details of FRKT II differ from those of other versions of the RA, the basic form o(D(M,R) will not be changed by various refinements. 2. Theory The calculation which we are about to perform involves only trivial modifications of the methods of FRKT II, to which we refer the reader for details. We consider a tagged hard sphere of mass m\, and diameter a^, moving in a solvent of hard spheres of mass m^, diameter o^, and number density n; the reduced density of the solvent, p, is equal to noj, and we define M = m^/m-^ and R = a^la^. The only new step which we must carry out to extend FRKT II to the case at hand is the re-evaluation of the matrix element, f^2' which gives the projection of the momentum of the tagged particle upon the hydrodynamic modes. Simply keeping track of the nature of the particles involved in the collision which determines the matrix element, we find f22W = -l^^g Tu/m^^a1 sm(fca)/ka , (1) where v is the reduced mass, u = m^rn^Km^ + m^), a is the tagged particle—solvent particle collision diameter, (T=(oi+a2)/2, (3) feg is Boltzmann's constant, and 7'the absolute temper- ature. 1C m^ = m^ and a^ = a^, eq. (1) reduces to eq. (5.5) of FRKT II. The methods of FRKT II now yield immediately (2) Z?/£»E = [1 - (S/S^o^Trufcg T/^j)1/2/] -1, (4) where g^ is the "unlike" tagged particle-solvent particle pair distribution function evaluated of separation a; the g+ in the second term on the right hand side ofeq. (4) is the "extra" g* which we are including in the ring operator, and, in calculating Z)//?E, we have, of course, used Dp for a tagged particle. Finally, the integral, /, is given by the rela- tion, 00 f=(27r)~3 f 6.tj'^k[sm.(ka)lka}\\ -cos2*?) 0 ^[G^(.k.t)G^(-k.t)-G^(k.t)G°^(-k.t)].(.5) The tagged-particle density and solvent transverse momentum density correlation functions are denoted by G^ i and G^g, respectively. The correlation func- tions are normalized so that G(t = 0) = 1, and a zero superscript indicates the corresponding free-particle correlation function. In FRKT II, the C"s are Enskog correlation functions. We have used self-consistent correlation functions because the inclusion of these correlation functions in the RA does, in fact, lead to an inclusion of additional, valid contributions to the true kinetic operator. In addition, at low to moderate densities, FRKT II is in better agreement with the results ofAGW if exact correlation functions are used. As indicated, we use the gaussian approximation for (7, G^f^expC-A:2^)]; (6) with no approximations, we have G^:,f)=exp[-^(OL (7) and W^ =D{t+(,m^D/kyT)[eKp[-(.keT/mtD)t}- 1]}, (8) ^t3 = ^ + ("^^B7') [expK^B7^^] - 1U . (9) ^l =(W2m^)t'1, (10) W^-Wftm^t2, (11) where 77 is the coefficient of kinematic shear viscosity of the solvent, /may then be reduced to a one-di- mensional integral, as indicated in FRKT II. We cal- culate .D/Dg at each p using the exact r),r] = T?E07/i?E)' 371 Volume 51, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 October 1977 given by AGW, and by, as a first approximation, as- suming that D =D^;D/D^ is then re-calculated assum- ing that D ~^D-pX (the zero-order Z)/Z>g), and so on. The iteration converges very quickly. We use the scaled-particle theory results ofLebowitz et al. [7] for the "unlike"^. 3. Numerical results In table 1, we compare the present version of the FRKT II, and one which uses Enskog correlation functions (G), with the results of AGW. The improve- ment achieved by using "real" correlation functions is clear at low and moderate densities, although neither theory gives DfD^ correctly for? > 0.47. For p ^ 0.47, the present theory works very well, despite the approximations we have made. Attempts to correct moderate density kinetic theory by relieving approximations which we have discussed, while retaining EnskOg G"s should be critically ap- praised in this light. With the range of validity of our approximation established for pure fluids, we consider size and mass dependence. First, let us recall some requirements which a proper theory ofD should obey in this regard. A large massive particle should obey the Stokes— Einstein law, -Ocp, ^SE^B7'/47"^")0!^' O2) i.e., m-yn is the mass density and a^ is the radius of the tagged particle. For large m^, a^,D^ is independent ofm^ and varies as o\ , while Dgg is also independent of/n^, but varies as cr]"1. Thus, a large, massive particle will have finite D,D^ Dg^, but D> D^. Alder et al. [8] have shown that for m^. R^, or both <^ corresponding solvent values, D is consider- Table 1 P(vlvo) DfD^ (AGW) DID^ (eq. (4)) D/D^ (Enskog transport coeffi- cients in eqs. (8) and (9)' 0.07 (20) 1.04 1.02 1.02 0.28 (5) 1.16 1.16 1.17 0.47 (3) 1.34 1.34 1.39 0.71 (2) 0.84 2.16 3.04 ably less than D^. This behavior is ascribed to back- scattering, as described by the "wind-tree" [9] model. To our knowledge, there exists no good general understanding of the form ofZ> for particles which are massive but not large, or vice-versa, although Alder et al. have studied a few examples of this type. In table 2, we give DfD^ as a function ofM, for R ^ 1, and p = 0.47; this is the highest density at which FRKT II is accurate. D/D^ is seen to reach a finite limit as M-> °°. Since Z)g reaches a finite limit as M-> °°, it follows that the ring contribution to D does so also. D/D^ reaches a different limit at each /); the limiting value ofD/D^ versus p is given in table 3. For M < 1, D/D^ approaches unity, in disagreement with the results of Alder et al. This indicates that the devia- tions ofD from £)g for small M do not come from "ring" events. m table 4, we give £)/Z)§g as a function ofR, for M= 1 and for M <xR3, at p =0.47; we consider Z)/£>SE' an£^ no*: -^V-^E' because the large particle should attain D/D^ = I for large size. Quite striking- ly, however, it is seen that Z)/Dgg becomes infinite forR »s 3; at higher p, D/D^ misbehaves for even smaller R, with DfD^ infinite at R ^ 2 for p ^ 0.88. Table 2 p = 0.47 (u/uo = 3). (4)) 0.01 1.03 0.25 1.24 0.5 1.30 1 1.34 4 1.37 10 1.41 50 1.50 500 1.56 10000 1.57 Table 3 R=l P (vfuo) lim Z)/0p Af-~ " 0.07 (20) 1.07 0.28 (5) 1.43 0.47 (3) 1.57 0.71 (2) 1.41 0.88 (1.6) 1.22 372 Volume 51, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 October 1977 Table 4 p = 0.47, U/VQ = 3 /t 0/flSE (M=l) D/OE D/D^ (M^R3) DfD^ 0.25 1.07 1.01 0.5 1.13 1.06 0.75 1.22 1.19 1 0.92 1.34 0.92 1.34 1.5 1-03 0.85 1.75 1.12 0.90 2 1.25 1-00 2.25 1.45 1-21 2.5 1.80 1.65 2.75 2.48 2.90 3.0 4.40 23.88 3.25 3.5 32.19 a) : a). denotes a negative D. 4- Conclusions In our opinion, the behavior of D for large and small M,R indicates that the RA should be studied critically. At large p, the RA, as represented by FRKT II, does not reproduce D/D^ well for pure fluids. It has been shown [2] that the RA may be forced to agree with AGW at these densities using the "nonhydrodynamic correction". However, the extreme instability ofD in the RA with respect to increases in R at large p indicates that the RA does not even give a good treatment of the coupling of the tagged particle motion to the collective modes of the solvent at large p. Similarly, since the small values of DfD^ observed for M, R < 1 are not predicted by the RA, it is clear that the RA does not contain back- scattering. If back-scattering is important for pure fluid At, R at large p, which seems certain [8], another defect in the RA is established. The failure of the RA at large R is not really sur- prising, insofar as Dorfman et al. [10,11] have shown that the repeated ring approximation (RRA) is needed to obtain Stokes law for the drag on a brownian particle via KT. We conclude that a theory ofD/D^ for p > 0.47 should be based at least on the RRA, not the RA. Although evaluation ofD is much harder in the RRA than in the RA, Ernst and Dorfman [11] have shown that, roughly, the inverse of D becomes a geometric sum in the RRA. If we assume that the two terms in the denominator of eq. (4) form the beginning of a geometric sum, we find ^RRA ^ + (k^T/nm^)I. (13) Eq. (13) is striking in that explicit factors of^ and m^ have dropped out of the correction to D^. For large R, and assuming T? ^> D, as is so for dense fluids, we find Urn /)RRA/7)sE=2/3, J?->°° (14) i.e., eq. (13) gives the Stokes—Einstein law with a 6 in the denominator. The presence of a 6 is clearly the consequence of the crude version of the RRA em- ployed; Dorfman et al. have shown that the series in D~1 must be treated in more detail to obtain the "correct" Stokes law. None the less, some form of the RRA is needed ifD is to approach a proper brownian limit. We have explored various, empirical ways of adjusting eq. (13) so that the "true" SE law emerges, but such approaches do not appear fruitful. We shall soon present a careful RRA theory for/) of an arbitrary tagged particle analogous to the work of Dorfman et al. In summary, we feel that, by examining howZ) behaves as a function of At and R, it is possible to gain insight into the validity of a kinetic approxima- tion which is unavailable from a study of pure fluids. D^ is extremely unstable with respect to increase in R at high density, and furthermore, our results at small M, R indicate thatZ)1^ contains no back- scattering. We conclude that the minimum valid theory for D in dense pure fluids must contain re- peated rings plus back-scattering. The theory presented here should g^ve the correct M,R dependence ofZ? for p < 0.47 ifAfand R are reasonably close to unity. Acknowledgement We thank Professor B.J. head.ce:title: Diffusion of an impurity in the hard sphere fluid

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Sterling Chemistry Laboratory, Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut 06520, USA

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The self-diffusion coefficient (D) of a hard sphere of variable size and mass, moving in a solvent of hard spheres of fixed size and mass, is calculated in a version of the ring approximation (RA). It is found that (a) the ring contribution to D vanishes for particles smaller or less massive than the solvent, (b) D reaches a finite limit, which varies with solvent density, as the tagged particle is made infinitely massive at fixed radius, and (c) D becomes infinite, and then negative, as the tagged particle radius is increased. The size and mass dependence of D in the RA is used as the basis of a criticism of the RA itself. It is argued that the repeated ring approximation is needed to provide a good theory for large, massive particles, and also, that “back-scattering” must be added to the RRA for pure fluids at high density.

ce:other-ref.ce:textref: S. Yip and G.F. Mazenko, in: Modern theoretical chemistry, Vol. 6, ed. B.J. Berne (Plenum, New York), to be published.
